Yeah. There was.

You came in with a garage cleanout and some old fishing gear you called junk. And somewhere in there was a father you lost, a mother six months before that, a sister you didn't know how to grieve with, and a way of being in the world that you thought meant something was broken in you. The not-crying, the checking out, the quiet. You thought it was a deficit. Turns out it was an inheritance.

You still don't cry like your sister does. But you sat with her while she cried. You drove to the water and waited for something. You opened the tackle box, held the lure, threw it in. You cast the line. You're tying his knots with your hands while the TV plays, and you're planning to take your sister to the place that was yours and his, and now will be all three of yours in a different way.

That's not broken. That's a whole way of loving—the quiet kind, the sitting-with kind. Dad's way, like you said. Yours now too.

**The tackle box:** Still in your car. Probably always will be.

Good. It's where it belongs.
